body:
I've only been using Rollup for a few days, so take this all with a grain of salt.

`path.resolve()` does in fact work with non-existing files.

```
> path.resolve('./main.css!cssmodules')
'/home/whatever/main.css!cssmodules'
```

So I would guess you could just specify the ! suffix in what you pass to `pass.resolve()` for your `externals`.

If for some reason this doesn't work, or if you don't want to have to specify (or simply don't know) what all the different suffixes are going to be, you could write a plugin with a custom `resolveId` function. See https://github.com/rollup/rollup/wiki/Plugins under "Creating plugins". Something I've found interesting and helpful is to write a testing plugin with one of those methods given on that wiki page that simply `console.log()`s its arguments, and returns undefined. This (generally) won't affect Rollup's behavior, but it does let you see what path names etc. Rollup is looking at under the hood.

@Conduitry you are right that `path.resolve('main.css!css')` actually does not throw an error. But rollup still throws an error even when I declare `main.css!css` as an external. For example,

``` js
// rollup.config.js
import path from 'path';

export default {
    entry: 'main.js',
    dest: 'bundle.js',
    external: [path.resolve('./main.css!css')],
}
```

``` js
// main.js
import './main.css!css';
```

``` js
// main.css
.mycss_class {
}
```

throws the following error (with rollup@0.25.4):

```
Error: Could not resolve ./main.css!css from /Users/joel/playground/test/main.js
    at /Users/joel/playground/test/node_modules/rollup/www/ROLLUP/rollup/src/Bundle.js:186:42
    at tryCatch (/Users/joel/playground/test/node_modules/rollup/www/ROLLUP/rollup/node_modules/es6-promise/lib/es6-promise/-internal.js:185:12)
    at invokeCallback (/Users/joel/playground/test/node_modules/rollup/www/ROLLUP/rollup/node_modules/es6-promise/lib/es6-promise/-internal.js:197:13)
    at publish (/Users/joel/playground/test/node_modules/rollup/www/ROLLUP/rollup/node_modules/es6-promise/lib/es6-promise/-internal.js:168:7)
    at flush (/Users/joel/playground/test/node_modules/rollup/www/ROLLUP/rollup/node_modules/es6-promise/lib/es6-promise/asap.js:87:5)
    at doNTCallback0 (node.js:407:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:336:13)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:477:11)
    at startup (node.js:117:18)
    at node.js:951:3
```

However, if I rename the `main.css` file to be `main.css!css`, then no error is thrown. To me, this seems like something that should be taken care of inside of Rollup itself (as opposed to a rollup plugin), since Rollup already handles `externals`, without plugins. Also, as far as I can tell, #410, #418, and [the wiki](https://github.com/rollup/rollup/wiki/JavaScript-API#external) did not intentionally create this behavior where the relative file must exist, which might indicate that this was just an oversight?

Ping.

If this is a feature that everyone's okay with, I'd be happy to work on a pull request for it.

issue.title: Allow external files to be non-existent, relative files. Fixes #532.
issue.body: See #532 for a detailed explanation of the problem this pull requests solves, and also the use case for non-existent, relative files to be treated as external dependencies.

issue.title: Allow for relative imports to be skipped, even if the file doesn't exist

repository.name: rollup-plugin-node-resolve
repository.description: This module has moved and is now available at @rollup/plugin-node-resolve / https://github.com/rollup/plugins/blob/master/packages/node-resolve

issue.body:
See rollup/rollup#532 for the explanation of the problem and the
use case for skipping relative imports for files that don't exist.
This pull request, in conjunction with rollup/rollup#572, resolves the
issue.

The revving of the rollup version in the package.json is because the
new test requires rollup@^0.25.7, and npm's caret semver behavior
[does not install 0.25.x when a dependency is listed at ^0.22.0](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#caret-ranges-123-025-004).
The source code itself does not require rollup@^0.25.7, just the test.

body: @Rich-Harris Thanks, look forward to updating all our rollup projects to the latest version!. I have also opened up rollup/rollup-plugin-node-resolve#32 which addresses this issue for those using rollup-plugin-node-resolve as well.
